results.title: Setting the scene designer interviews: Chris Kennedy
results.brief_description: A co-production between AFTRS and ACMI for ACMI’s Setting the Scene exhibition. Chris Kennedy talks about the two different approaches he took for two films, the building of a town in The Proposition and finding already existing locations for The Road. This was part of the Landscape Spaces section of the exhibition.

results.title: Passion fish
results.creator_credit: John Sayles, Maggie Renzi, Sarah Green and Atchafalaya Films Inc
results.brief_description: Mary McDonnell is May-Alice, star of a popular day-time soap, who was on her way to a leg waxing session when she was knocked down by a mad taxi-driver. Now confined to a wheelchair, she has only one option left - to return to the Bayou she so defiantly left as a sassy teen. Hiding out in the house of her long dead parents, May-Alice becomes the patient from hell, terrorising a series of nurses and driving each and every one of them from the house. Then Chantelle, a no-nonsense nurse from Chicago, arrives. Chantelle couldn’t be more different than May-Alice and it seems she too will be given her marching orders. Then, unexpectedly, differences are put aside, secrets emerge, old friends drift into their lives and each finds an unlikely romance as they give themselves up to the forces of fate and friendship. Brilliant performances by the cast make this film a rewarding and worthwhile experience.

results.title: Orchestra rehearsal = Prova d'orchestra
results.creator_credit: Federico Fellini, Albatros Produktion and Radiotelevisione Italiana
results.brief_description: A television crew arrives to film the members of an orchestra rehearsing. The various musicians bicker and debate the merits of their individual contributions. Performing for the camera, they begin to challenge the authority of the conducter. As the situation turns chaotic and their rehearsal room begins to be demolished by a building crew, they all turn to the conductor for the restablishment of order. Maintaining a finely absurd comic tone throughout, “Orchestra Rehearsal” is a celebration of the meditative power of music and art. It is also a witty parable on the entropic contradictions that are threatening to tear modern Italy apart. With this short but elegant film, Fellini signalled a retreat from the lavish carnivalesque cinema he explored in the Sixties and Seventies. However, this does not mean this is not a suberbly directed work. In fact this was a return to form for Fellini, and his concern with the meaning and function of art in an increasingly alienated society is more expressively explored in “Orchestra Rehearsal” than it has been in any other film since “8 1/2”.

results.title: Enchanted April
results.creator_credit: Mike Newell, Ann Scott, Greenpoint, Miramax Films and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description: In a beautifully played ensemble piece four Englishwomen desert their dull and oppressive lives in post World War I London and escape to the Italian Riviera for a months holiday in a majestic castle. Once there, the castle and its magnificent surroundings work a special magic on the four women. Each find their worries slowly disappearing, their personalities changing and together, the four discover a friendship unknown to the likes of any of them before. Stars Miranda Richardson, Joan Plowright, Polly Walker and Josie Lawrence. From the novel by Elizabeth Von Arnim.

results.title: La Boheme
results.brief_description: Filmed in 1967 at the Teatro alla Scala, Milan, Puccini’s opera is performed here with Mirella Freni (Mimi) and the chorus and orchestra of the Teatro alla Scala. It is set in the students’ quarter of Paris, where gaiety and pathos rub elbows. The opera is seen to laugh as well as weep. It achieves balance between the gay and the pathetic, the realistic and the impressionistic, due to its solid theatrical foundations. Designed and directed by Franco Zeffirelli.

results.title: Le Dejeuner Sur L'herbe = Picnic in the Grass
results.brief_description:
Jean Renoir never made any secret that ‘Le Dejeuner sur L’Herbe’ was inspired by the impressionist paintings of his father Auguste Renoir, and also of Edouard Monet. A pompous Parisian professor concerned with artificial insemination, finds himself seduced by the mysteries of the countryside and the farmer’s daughter. Shot almost entirely at Les Collettes, the Renoir family home near Cannes, its sensuous colours and sunlit images derive from the Impressionists.

Credits: Producer, Ginette Doynel ; director, Jean Renoir ; writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Joseph Kosma.
Cast: Paul Meurisse, Catherine Rouvel, Fernand Sardou, Ingrid Nordine.

results.title: Carmen
results.creator_credit: Patrice Ledoux, Opera Film Produzione, Production Marel Dassault and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Two of the leading figures in opera today, Placido Domingo and Julia Migenes-Johnson, star in this sumptious and true interpretation of Bizet’s carmen. The ingredients of this romantic opera are a film-maker’s dream: a torrid love story, a tempestuous score, set against a backdrop of glorious Spanish sunshine. Added to this production is the authenticity of Andalusian dance.

results.title: Toute la Memoire du Monde = All the Memory of the World
results.brief_description:
Following the journey of a book from its arrival at the Legal Deposit office, rue de Richelieu, to the consultation room, Alain Resnais takes the audience through the meanders of the French National Library and the treasures it contains. Resnais instructed his crew that he wanted to move through the library like a fish in water or like a rocket. This explains the fluidity of the travelling and tacking shots which gave the film such a dynamism while the subject was totally inert.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Alain Resnais ; writer, Remo Forlani ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Maurice Jarre, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jacques Dumesnil [narration only].

results.title: Les Mistons = the Brats
results.brief_description:
The awakening sexuality of a group of boys during a summer in Nimes is focused on Bernadette, the sister of one of them, and her short-lived love affair with Gerard, a physical education teacher. The blend of sensuality and nostalgia, tenderness and irony recalls Renoir, especially ‘Partie de Campagne’. The voice-over narration ensures that we see Bernadette - the first of Truffaut’s succession of inacessible women - through the eyes of the boys.

Credits: Producer, Robert Lachenay ; director, Francois Truffaut ; photography, Jean Malige ; music, Maurice Leroux
Cast: Gerard Blain, Bernadette Lafont, Michel Francois [naration].
